snippet: When the war against Al Qaeda winds down, the responsibility for mopping up scattered remnants of the group will likely fall to United States law enforcement and intelligence agencies.
abstract: Jeh C Johnson, Obama administration’s top lawyer at the Pentagon, speaks of challenges that will arise when war against Al Qaeda winds down; warns responsibility for mopping up scattered remnants of group will likely fall to United States law enforcement and intelligence agencies, and notes that pressing questions will arise about what to do with military detainees still being held without trial as wartime prisoners.
lead_paragraph: When the war against Al Qaeda winds down, the responsibility for mopping up scattered remnants of the group will likely fall to United States law enforcement and intelligence agencies.

headline.seo: Pentagon Counsel Looks Ahead to Post-Qaeda Legal Challenges
headline.main: Pentagon Counsel Speaks of Post-Qaeda Challenges
headline.print_headline: Pentagon Counsel Speaks Of Post-Qaeda Challenges
